Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Collaborative Modeling for Distributed Sensing and Real-time Intelligent Control to Improve Battery Manufacturing Productivity and Efficiency

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is an integrated research and education study centered on collaborative sensing information processing, and an intelligent online control framework for battery manufacturing. It aims to integrate decision theory with real-time control, which will allow the full potential of distributed sensor networks to improve production system responsiveness, productivity and overall efficiency. The methodology includes the following tasks: 1) establish a virtual multi-layer sensing framework and event-based modeling to directly model distributed-sensor systems, 2) develop a collaborative information processing framework to effectively identify system transient loss and root causes of system inefficiency, and create a system learning method to optimize sensor network design, 3) establish an intelligent online control method to integrate decision theory with control for adaptive resource allocation and distributed management, and 4) validate these methods using simulation and real data through collaboration with industrial partners.

If successful, this CAREER project will advance the state of the art on distributed sensor networks by contributing new concepts, criteria, and algorithms to its system level real-time decision making capabilities, and create an enabling methodology for next-generation plant-wide sensing, information processing and control. Accomplishing these goals will lead to dramatic cost reductions as a result of reduced downtime, improved quality and system efficiency, boosting the competitiveness of U.S. industries and the nation's economy. The CAREER education program will make a positive contribution to workforce training through curriculum and lab development, real-world problem solving and other outreach activities, with a focus on broadening participation of underrepresented groups. Dissemination through conference/journal publications and international/industrial collaborations will lead to exposure of these research results to a wide range distributed sensor networks that are of vital importance to the nation's economic growth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The strong strategic impetus for energy independence imposes growing demands for green energy products with improved functionality and time to market, which puts an enormous strain on production systems. The goal of this CAREER project is to establish a collaborative sensing information processing and intelligent decision-making framework for battery manufacturing that will integrate decision theory with online control to significantly improve system responsiveness, productivity, and overall efficiency. This research aims to establish the scientific and technological foundation for understanding the real-time properties of sensor network equipped stochastic manufacturing systems.

With the support of this NSF CAREER award, novel methods for next-generation plant-wide sensing, information processing and online control have been developed. 

1) A virtual multi-layer sensing framework and an event-based modeling approach has been developed to directly model distributed sensor systems which can reflect battery manufacturing operation. The new data-driven modeling is a hybrid approach that combines the understanding of physical laws of production systems and multi-layer sensor data. The hybrid data-driven model enables the capturing of all the activities, resources, and disruption events from distributed sensor systems. The modeling approach has been extended from a serial line structure to a networked structure. This high fidelity model enhances the understanding of mapping functions from complex industrial sensor data to multi-stage production processes.

2) Collaborative information processing on the sensing framework is established to effectively identify manufacturing system transient loss and root causes of system inefficiency, and to create a system learning method to optimize sensor network design. Data-enabled manufacturing system-level diagnostic and prognostic methods have been developed to analyze system real-time performance. The hybrid data-enabled modeling and analysis approach has been extended to more complicated stochastic scenarios. 

3) An intelligent online control method is developed to integrate decision theory with real-time control for dynamic resource allocation and distributed management. A real-time control scheme has been built to adaptively allocate limited resources for maintenance and material handling to improve system productivity and energy efficiency. Various control strategies are compared, for example, real-time resilient centralized control methods for the stochastic production system and distributed control scheme. The limitation, advantages and applications of different control schemes are analyzed.

4) Machine learning based control algorithms are developed in dealing with more complicated and highly stochastic scenarios. The learning-based control methods adopt the understandings obtained from the data-driven modeling and analysis. A deep reinforcement learning algorithm has been built to obtain optimal preventive maintenance policy and corrective maintenance policy in a manufacturing system. Furthermore, a reinforcement learning algorithm has been built for online task assignment of material handling gantries/robots to improve the operational efficiency of an automated work cell.

In summary, the real-time data-driven modeling and control methods have fundamentally changed the traditional long-term steady state analysis approach, and filled the gaps in the areas of real-time dynamic manufacturing system modeling, performance analysis, and online adaptive control by utilizing sensor data. These methods have been verified with industrial testbed and real data through collaboration with industrial partners.

This award has broader impacts on education and outreach. The research findings of this project have been incorporated in the curricula at Stony Brook University and the University of Virginia, and benefit both undergraduate and graduate teaching. The project has trained four PhD student (including one female), three MS students, and two undergraduate students. The PI has actively partnered with the Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) Program at Stony Brook University, which is designed to increase the numbers of traditionally underrepresented minority students who pursue degrees in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) majors. The PI has also collaborated with local high schools in the Long Island, NY area. Four K-12 students have been actively involved in the research activities on this project and the outcomes have been presented at various science competitions and science fairs. The results from the project have also been broadly disseminated to the academic community and the general public through conference/journal publications. This award has led to the publication of 28 journal papers, 1 book chapter, and 23 conference papers, and the accomplishment of four PhD theses and 3 MS theses. Through the NSF supplemental INTERN award, two PhD students were provided with intern training opportunities at an industrial R&D Center. These industrial intern opportunities not only provided training to graduate students but also enabled the transfer of technology and ideas from academic research to real world applications.
